route.name: Resonance of Alicia (Maelle – Canon Route)
route.subtitle: A fan-made sequel told from the echo between Alicia and Maelle
route.description: Caught between a burned childhood and a painted ideal, Maelle awakens as a resonance tied to Alicia's body in the real world. To exist fully again, she must confront the memories Aline tried to paint over.

chapters.title: PROLOGUE — The Girl in the Gap

pages.text:
When the Canvas shattered, Maelle did not fall with it.

Not completely.

She was never just paint.

She was an answer to a question Aline refused to face: "What if Alicia had never burned? What if my daughter could walk unscarred, confident, and whole?" 

Maelle was that fantasy given form — a body painted from the negative space of Alicia's fear.

When the painted world collapsed, fantasy and reality collided.

The Canvas disintegrated.

Alicia's real body remained in the true Lumière — scarred, voiceless from the fire that burned her throat, alive but forever changed.

Maelle became the line drawn between them.

In the void after collapse, she floats.

She feels the absence of color first — like someone turned down the saturation on existence until it was all sketch and no fill.

She hears two heartbeats:

One slow, steady, wrapped in the silence of a body that can no longer speak.

One wild and echoing, belonging to a boy made half of paint and half of stubbornness.

Alicia.
Verso.

Maelle is pulled between them.

She is too painter-made to fully escape with the Writers' magic.
Too real to completely vanish with the Canvas.

So she settles where opposing truths meet:

The gap between "what happened" and "what should have happened."

There, in that impossible space, she waits.

And in the dark, she hears the same whisper Verso did:

"A Painter has broken the world.
A Writer must rewrite it.

But what of the girl who was painted to be a rewrite?"

She wakes to the sound of her own name.

Not "Maelle."

"Alicia."

The word drags her upward like someone tugging on a thread stitched through her chest.

She rises through layers of memory and paint.

A bedroom half-remembered.
A studio that never existed this way.
A ship’s deck under impossible skies.

Every scene blurs into the next until she stumbles into a narrow street that feels like both a memory and a guess.

Children run past her.

Their faces are undone — eyes blank, features half-sketched as if someone started drawing them and then changed their mind.

One of those children is her.

Alicia-at-eight scrapes her knee on the cobblestones and looks up toward a window glowing with warm, late-night studio light.

"Get up, ma petite," a voice echoes from above. "We don’t bleed for cobblestones."

Maelle remembers this.

Except she doesn’t.

These are Alicia’s memories, not hers.

She was born fully formed on the day of Expedition 33, painted from all the things Alicia might have been if a fire hadn’t rewritten her body.

But here, in this liminal street, both versions of the girl exist at once.

She steps closer.

The child version of her — of Alicia — looks up.

For one terrifying second, those unfinished eyes focus directly on Maelle.

"Who are you?" the child asks.

Maelle hesitates.

She doesn’t have a simple answer.

"I’m… you," she says finally. "From a different draft."

The child frowns. "Mama says I’m already a masterpiece," she replies. "She just has to fix a few things."

Behind her, the glowing window flickers.

Sometimes it shows Aline at the easel, sleeves rolled up, face streaked with color.

Sometimes it shows nothing but blank brick.

The street can’t decide whether this was a night with art or without it.

Maelle reaches out.

Her hand passes through the child’s shoulder like smoke.

She feels a sting — not in her fingers, but behind her eyes.

This is the life she was painted to overwrite.

Alicia’s scraped knees.
Her choked-back sobs.
The way she tried not to cry because crying made Aline look away.

Maelle was meant to be the polished version.

The girl who didn’t flinch.
The girl who didn’t burn.

But that girl never existed without the messy, frightened child in front of her.

"I’m sorry," Maelle whispers.

The child tilts her head. "For what?"

Maelle doesn’t know how to explain being sorry for existing.

For taking up the space of someone else’s future.

For being loved for the wrong reasons.

The scene begins to unravel.

The cobblestones smear into lines of ink.

The window light stretches into a narrow beam that becomes a lantern flame.

Smoke curls at the edges of the world — thin at first, then thicker.

Maelle knows what comes next.

The fire.

The night that turned Alicia’s life into a series of before-and-after images.

The night that spawned Maelle as a desperate repaint.

She tries to hold the street in place.

"Not yet," she begs. "Please."

The world doesn’t listen.

It never learned to listen to girls like her.

Something interrupts the collapse.

Pages slam together overhead.

Shelves rise from the fog, lined with books whose spines are labeled not with titles, but with emotions and dates.

"Fear, Age 9."
"Hope, Before the Fire."
"Rage, After."

The burning street folds in on itself and becomes an illustration inside a book she hasn’t opened yet.

Maelle finds herself standing in a vast hall of stacked narratives.

A figure steps out from between the shelves, face obscured by floating script.

"Welcome to the Scribes’ Archive," the figure says, voice echoing like a bedtime story never actually told. "We kept what your mother tried to paint over."

Words swirl around Maelle’s ankles like fog.

She looks down at her own hands.

They are clean. Unscarred. Perfectly painted.

"I’m not Alicia," she says.

"No," the figure agrees. "You’re the version of her that wasn’t allowed to happen. Which means you belong to us as much as you belonged to her."

Maelle takes a breath that isn't tied to lungs.

Somewhere far away, a girl with a burned face and a ruined voice stirs in the waking world.

Somewhere else, in a fractured cathedral square, a boy made of paint and skin agrees to help rewrite a broken world.

Maelle straightens her shoulders.

"Then show me," she says. "Show me what she was. Show me what I am. Show me everything Aline tried to hide."

The Archive opens.

Her story — their story — begins to turn its own pages.

The Archive smells like old ink and unfinished arguments.

Shelves stretch in every direction, too tall and too crooked to belong to any real building. Some lean at angles that would be impossible if gravity were paying attention.

The books are not organized by author or title.

They are arranged by wound.

"Fear, Age 9."
"Resentment, After the Fire."
"Joy, Brief and Unsupervised."

Maelle turns slowly, feeling the weight of a thousand unwritten apologies pressing down on her.

"What is this place?" she asks.

The figure made of script steps closer.

Letters drift around them like a slow blizzard — fragments of sentences that never made it into official history.

"The Scribes’ Archive," they repeat. "We are what remains of the Writers’ work. Not the grand narratives — those were burned, banned, or painted over. We kept the margins. The drafts. The things your mother tried to erase when they didn’t flatter her story."

Words slide across their face, forming a name Maelle can’t quite hold.

"You’re one of them," she realizes. "A Writer."

The figure inclines their head. "A remnant of one," they correct. "Enough of me survived in footnotes and diary pages to be irritating."

Maelle looks down at her own hands.

They are perfect.

No burns.
No scars.
No tremor when she flexes her fingers.

Alicia’s body does not look like this.

"Why am I here?" Maelle asks.

"Because you’re an argument," the Scribe says simply.

They gesture, and a book slides off a shelf and floats between them.

On its spine is written:

"ALICIA DESSENDRE — POSSIBLE LIVES"

"Painters," the Scribe continues, "insisted you be one thing: a masterpiece. A proof that the right color in the right place could fix anything."

The book opens.

Inside, Maelle sees herself as she existed in the Canvas — laughing on the deck of a ship that never sailed, standing before a Monolith that never existed in the real world.

"We," the Scribe adds, "insisted on remembering the burned girl underneath."

The page turns.

Now she sees Alicia after the fire.

Bandages covering burned skin.
Shadows under her eyes.
Aline at her side, face frozen in a smile that looks like a painting trying to hold back a scream.

Words spill down the page:

"REFUSES TO LOOK AT HER OWN DAUGHTER.
PAINTS INSTEAD.
CALLS IT LOVE."

Maelle flinches.

"She was trying," she says automatically.

"Of course she was," the Scribe replies. "Monsters rarely begin as monsters. They begin as people who are allowed to keep fixing things the same way long after it has stopped working. Aline loved Alicia. She just loved the version of Alicia in her head more."

The pen-scratch sound of the Archive grows louder, like it approves of the phrasing.

Another page.

Now she sees herself.

Maelle on the Canvas.

Confident. Unscarred. Leading an expedition. Laughing with Verso. Throwing herself at gods and monsters with a recklessness Alicia never had the chance to develop.

"You were painted to be a correction," the Scribe says. "Aline’s attempt to repaint the parts of Alicia’s life she couldn’t stand to look at. She took the pain, hid it in the dark, and made you out of the light she wished was left."

The image ripples.

Maelle sees the edges of each scene marked with tiny, angry notes in a cramped Writer’s hand:

"SHE WAS AFRAID HERE."
"SHE WAS EXHAUSTED."
"THIS BRAVERY COST HER MORE THAN ALINE KNOWS."

She realizes those notes are not just about Alicia.

They’re about her.

About Maelle.

"So which one am I?" she asks. "The burned girl she abandoned? Or the painted girl she perfected?"

Ink gathers at the Scribe’s feet.

"That," they say, "is why you’re still here."

"Verso is a fracture between Painter and world," the Scribe explains. "You are a fracture between girl and ideal. Writers and Painters both claimed you. Painters say you’re proof they can make anyone better. Writers say you’re proof that what was done to Alicia cannot be erased with a prettier draft."

They close the book softly.

"When the Canvas fell, most fictions died with it. But contested texts? Stories no one could agree on? Those linger."

Maelle feels it in her chest — a constant pull in two directions.

One toward a scarred body in the waking world, a girl who remembers the fire and can no longer speak.

One toward a boy standing in a fractured city square, half-paint and half-grief.

"If you want to exist," the Scribe says, "you will have to decide which of those pulls you answer. Or find a way to answer both."

"How?" she asks.

The Scribe gestures to the shelves.

"By walking into the memory everyone keeps trying to edit," they say. "The night of the fire."

A single book slides forward.

Its cover is blackened at the edges.

Its title is simple:

"THE NIGHT EVERYTHING BURNED"

Maelle reaches out.

Her painted fingers do not burn when they touch the charred leather.

She opens the book.

And steps inside.

Heat hits her first.

Not the distant warmth of a sun in a painted sky.

Real heat.

She stands in the family studio.

The walls are lined with canvases at various stages of completion. Some are only sketches. Some are fully rendered scenes of Lumière that never existed quite this beautifully.

The smell is exactly what Alicia remembers:

Turpentine.
Charcoal.
The faint metallic tang of fear.

Outside the tall windows, the city is quiet.

Inside, time holds its breath.

Alicia sits by the window.

Older now than the child from the street, but not by much.

Her hair is longer, pulled carefully to one side to hide the worst of the scars that crescent along her jaw and neck.

In this version of the scene, the fire hasn’t happened yet.

But the terror of its possibility hangs in the air like smoke waiting for a match.

Aline’s voice drifts in from the hallway — half-muttered, half-prayer.

"If I can fix this piece, I can fix everything…"

Maelle feels the world tug at her.

This is supposed to play out a certain way.

The lantern on the table is supposed to tip.

The canvas soaked in oil is supposed to catch.

Alicia is supposed to survive, burned and broken — her face scarred, her voice stolen by the flames — never quite the same.

Maelle is supposed to be born years later as a painted apology.

The Archive has dropped her before the match is struck.

"Can I change it?" she whispers.

No one answers.

She steps closer to Alicia.

The girl startles, then freezes.

For one impossible second, Alicia sees her.

Not as a stranger.

As a possibility.

Her eyes widen. "You’re… me," she says.

Maelle’s throat tightens.

"I’m what she wanted you to be," Maelle replies. "What you might have been if tonight went differently."

Alicia glances at the door where Aline’s footsteps are getting nearer.

"Does it?" she asks. "Does tonight go differently?"

Maelle looks at the lantern.

At the edges of the canvas soaked in oil.

At the way the scene hums with inevitability.

She doesn’t know how fixed this memory is.

All she knows is that every version she’s ever seen of Alicia’s life begins here.

With fire.

The door flies open.

Aline storms in, arms full of canvases.

She looks haunted — not by spirits, but by possibilities.

"Just a few more revisions," she mutters. "If I can fix this one, I can fix her. I can fix all of it."

She moves through the studio like a storm given a human shape.

She doesn’t see Alicia.

Not really.

She sees the paintings.

The lantern wobbles as her elbow clips the table.

Flame kisses oil.

Maelle lunges.

Her hand passes through the lantern and catches only heat.

The scene resists her.

Some events are drafts.

Some are anchors.

Fire races up the canvas.

In one version of this memory, Alicia screams.

In another, she doesn’t.

In some, Aline grabs her first.
In others, she grabs the paintings.

The Archive shows Maelle all of them at once.

Flames fork into different paths and then drag themselves back together as if an invisible hand keeps forcing them into a single, sanctioned story.

Maelle stands at the center of it.

She hears Alicia’s raw, child-voice: "Mama, please—"

She hears Aline’s frantic, Painter-voice: "I can fix this, I can paint over this, I can—"

She hears something else underneath.

The steady scratch of a pen in the margins, refusing to let any of it be pretty.

Smoke claws at Maelle’s throat, even though she doesn’t need to breathe.

She understands, suddenly, why the Writers and Painters tore each other apart.

Painters want to change the picture instead of the behavior.

Writers want to force the picture to match the truth, no matter how ugly.

People like Alicia get crushed between those instincts.

People like Maelle get invented to make everyone feel better about it.

She steps toward the fire.

The floor here is made of sentences.

Every step she takes rewrites something small:

"SHE WAS CLUMSY" becomes "SHE WAS RUSHED."

"SHE DIDN’T LISTEN" becomes "SHE WAS NEVER WARNED."

Maelle realizes the Archive isn’t asking her to change the past.

It’s asking her to decide how the past is told.

The scene trembles.

Alicia reaches for her own face as the heat surges.

Aline reaches for the nearest canvas instead.

Flame dances between them.

Maelle stands exactly where the story splits.

She could let the official version continue — the one where Alicia becomes a wound Aline paints around.

She could try to erase the fire entirely — paint over it the way Aline always wished she could.

Or she could do something harder.

She could keep the fire.

Keep the hurt.

And refuse to let Alicia be reduced to a tragic origin or Maelle to a pretty replacement.

"I’m not here to fix you," she tells the scene — tells Alicia, tells herself. "I’m here to make sure what happened to you is yours, not hers."

The flames roar.

Pages turn themselves.

The Night Everything Burned locks into place as a story that will not be edited out again.

The studio dissolves into ash and ink.

When the smoke clears, Maelle is standing back in the Archive, lungs burning with a pain that isn’t entirely metaphor.

The Scribe watches her quietly.

"Well?" they ask.

Maelle straightens.

"I'm not her masterpiece," she says. "I'm her consequence. And I'm Alicia's choice." 

Somewhere far away, a scarred girl with a voiceless throat dreams of a ship and a boy with painted hands.

Somewhere else, in a fractured cathedral, that boy walks toward his first fracture.

Their paths are no longer separate.

Whether the world is ready or not, Maelle is done being a draft.
